results.title: The Lost Thing: character
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘The Lost Thing’ production team discusses the challenges they faced creating the friendly and unthreatening character of the lost thing and the techniques used to convey emotion in a character that does not speak and has no facial features.

results.title: The Claim
results.creator_credit: Michael Winterbottom, Andrew Eaton and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Directed by Michael Winterbottom (Butterfly kiss, Wonderland, 24 hour party people), “The Claim” is an adaptation of the Thomas Hardy novel “The Mayor of Casterbridge”. Set in the frontier town Kingdom Come, California, in the year 1867, “The Claim” plots the story of Daniel Dillon played by Peter Mullan (My name is Joe), a man who has amassed a fortune in mining and is the unofficial ruler the town. One day three people arrive in Kingdom Come who will upset Dillon’s world. Two are the wife (Natassja Kinski) and child (Sarah Polley) that he sold in a Faustian pact twenty years earlier in exchange his first gold claim, from which all his fortunes spilled. The other is a stranger, Dalglish (Wes Bentley), a land surveyor for the railroad who is seeking a path for the train line. Dalglish’s decision will determine the future of the town and Dillon, accustomed to getting his own way, seeks to sway the decision in his favour. Shot in Alberta, Canada, “The Claim” is a magnificent looking film that portrays frontier life as rudimentary, dangerous and lawless. Milla Jovovich also stars as a bar room singer, romantically invlolved with Dillon. Features a score by Michael Nyman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Winterbottom, Andrew Eaton and United Artists Corporation

results.title: Shaun Tan's The Lost Thing: From book to film. The Interviews
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Set in a city overrun by bureaucracy, Shaun Tan’s picture book ‘The Lost Thing’ tells the story of a boy who befriends a strange creature that doesn’t appear to fit in any of the available pigeon holes.
Melbourne-based production company Passion Pictures Australia invited Shaun to direct an animated version of ‘The Lost Thing’, and several years later, the Oscar®-winning short film emerged.
The ACMI exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From book to film’(showing in Gallery Two from 16th July 2013 to 19th January 2014), features Shaun’s exquisite original drawings and working sketches alongside exclusive footage of the animators and sound artists, demonstrating how the drawings were brought to life on screen with movement, sound effects, music and narration.
These eight interview segments are each based on a particular production process in the making of ‘The Lost Thing’.
The eight segments feature interviews with Shaun Tan (writer/co director), Sophie Byrne (producer), Tom Bryant (3D artist), Leo Baker (animator), John Kassab (sound designer) and Michael Yezerski (composer).
In addition to the interviews, there is a wealth of ‘behind-the-scenes’ footage, rough drafts of designs and animation wireframes from the very early stages of production.

results.title: Asking Around
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Shaun Tan (author and co-director)describes some of his original concepts for the book of ‘The Lost Thing’ and how these were translated and changed for the film adaptation. Other interviewees Tom Bryant (3D artist)and Leo Baker (animator)discuss points of similarity and difference between the book and film.
